clinical_study.brief_title: Intraoperative Warming During Major Surgical Procedures Using the Esophageal Temperature Management System
clinical_study.official_title: Intraoperative Warming During Major Surgical Procedures Using the Esophageal Temperature Management System

lead_sponsor.agency: Advanced Cooling Therapy, Inc., d/b/a Attune Medical

clinical_study.source: Advanced Cooling Therapy, Inc., d/b/a Attune Medical

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study is to assess the effectiveness of EnsoETM as a supplemental warming device compared to the standard of care warming practice in patients having major surgery.

detailed_description.textblock:
Maintaining patient's body temperature is of major importance in patients undergoing surgical procedures and existing methods to warm patients to maintain perioperative normothermia have limitations. This results in as many as half of patients undergoing surgery developing inadvertent hypothermia during and/or after their procedure. The EnsoETM is an Esophageal Temperature Management (ETM) device consisting of a multi-chambered silicone tube connected to a heat exchanger and placed in the esophagus, providing highly efficient heat transfer to a patient. The EnsoETM potentially improves the ability to control patient temperature by eliminating the disadvantages of existing methods while maintaining the functionality of the orogastric tube that it replaces.
The primary objective of this study is to measure the number of degree-hours spent below 37°C intraoperatively and until recovery in the PACU. This measure will be compared between patients having standard management of body temperature to patients having the EnsoETM placed as an additional warming device.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Time from intubation until extubation, approximately 3-12 hours
primary_outcome.description: Number of degree-hours spent below 37 °C intraoperatively until recovery in the PACU and return to 37°C body temperature.

secondary_outcome.description: Units of blood transfused during the procedure

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From approximately 10-30 minutes after patient is transferred from the OR
secondary_outcome.description: Patient core temperature reading on arrival in PACU

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From PACU admission until PACU discharge, approximately 2-4 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Routine pain score measured on the Numerical Rating Pain Scale from 1-10, with 10 being most intense pain possible. Collected approximately every 30 minutes, or more frequently if patient reports severe pain.

arm_group.description: Participants receive esophageal warming in addition to standard of care surface warming from the time they enter the OR until released to the PACU.
Participants receive standard of care surface warming from the time they enter the OR until released to the PACU.

intervention.description: Patients having major surgery will have the EnsoETM device placed after induction of general anesthesia in addition to standard of care surface warming.
Forced air warming device will be placed on the patient according to standard practice.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Provision of signed and dated informed consent form
- Male or female, ages 18 years and older
- Scheduled for major surgical procedures requiring general anesthesia and with no known contraindication to having an orogastric tube placed for the duration of the surgery
- The time in the OR is expected to last at least 180 minutes
Exclusion Criteria:
- Esophageal strictures (risk of perforation)
- Patients with known esophageal deformity or evidence of esophageal trauma (for example history of esophagectomy, previous swallowing disorders, achalasia, etc.)
- Known ingestion of acidic or caustic poisons within the prior 24 hours.
- Patients with <40 kg of body mass
- Coagulopathy
- Severe facial trauma
- Surgical procedures lasting less than 3 hours
